title: A Case of Bell's Palsy in a 35-Year-Old Female
clinical_history: A 35-year-old female, Sarah, presented with a 2-day history of sudden onset of right-sided facial weakness. She reported that she woke up with a feeling of numbness and weakness on the right side of her face, which made it difficult for her to smile, close her eye, or move her eyebrow on the affected side. She denied any history of trauma, infection, or recent travel. She also reported experiencing taste disturbances and hyperacusis (sensitivity to sound) on the affected side.

nprs.affected_area: right-sided headache and discomfort around the ear

aggrevating_factors: talking, eating, and exposure to loud noises
picture: 24-hour picture: The patient reports that her symptoms have been constant over the past 2 days, with no significant changes throughout the day.
easing_factors: resting, avoiding loud noises, and using warm compresses on the affected side
past_history: No significant past medical history, but she had a similar episode of transient facial weakness on the left side 5 years ago, which resolved on its own within a week.
medical_history: Generally healthy, with no chronic medical conditions
medications: Currently taking no medications, but was prescribed prednisone by her primary care physician, which she started 2 days ago
personal_history: Married with two young children, works part-time as a marketing specialist, and enjoys hiking and reading in her free time
imaging: MRI of the brain and facial nerve conduction studies are pending
